I also got another error that occured while automatically activating bundle org.eclipse.mylar.monitor.usage and other small exceptions due to the same problem.

However, if I check out and start the plugins org.eclipse.mylar.tasks.core and org.eclipse.mylar.tasks.ui in addition, then it works fine (apart from the extra plugins I have to check out).

I think this is because the (unique/default) context store is contributed by org.eclipse.mylar.tasks.ui.

BTW, Mik, it makes sense to maintain the context store as a extension since the current implementation only supports 1? If I'm not wrong, the implementation gets the first contributed one.

Or are you planning to support multiple context stores at the same time?

Yes Willian, this is the problem.

No, I don't think it makes sense to support multiple context stores, the goal is to have 'pluggable' context stores, e.g.:
* support running ..context.core in a headless environment with a non-workspace context store
* support RCP applications that may not be able to depend on java.io or eclipse.resources

But as you point out the current thing is weird because the store comes from tasks.ui.  It should really come from an extension of tasks.ui, so I'll probably move it into mylar.resources or mylar.ide.

Humm... ok, but this can be a source of confusion, since the context store gets the first one, i.e. if someone wants to integrate parts of mylar + its own context store and accidentally gets together the default filesystem-based store and starts thinking why it doesn't work...

Perhaps move the filesystem-based context store to its own plugin and document the extension point with a warning on how it works.

Just my 0.02 cents :)

Sounds right, I'll do something like that, not sure if it will warrant it's own plug-in.  In addition to documenting this we'll have to be defensive to multiple context stores being declared and throw a proper error.
This will have to wait until after 0.8 goes out.

Fixed by making the log file location fall back to the plug-in state location (in .metadata folder) if there is no context store installed.  We still need to consider Willian's points on what happens if there is an attempt to install multiple context stores, but that will need to wait post 1.0 and will be dependent on bug 130658 and Eclipse 3.3 efforts to share .metadata folder state (Platfform bug 154097).
